title: How to Make Spline Dovetail Joints

steps.headline: Start by making the jig as shown in the picture and drawing.
steps.description: Use 18mm MDF for strength, and make sure the included angle is exactly 90 degrees to ensure stability. The sizes given are advisory; though keep the top plate as large as possible for maximum router support.

steps.headline: The dovetail splines are inserted through an already assembled mitre joint, so the first step is to assemble the joint and glue it up.
steps.description: It’s a good idea to use biscuits to help hold the joint in alignment.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/6\/6d\/SplineDovetail_04.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/6\/6d\/SplineDovetail_04.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Clamp your assembled mitre joint in the bench vice so it faces upwards.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/45\/SplineDovetail_05.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/45\/SplineDovetail_05.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Mark out the dovetail spacings across the joint.
steps.description: Start about 10mm in from each edge for the outside pair, and then divide the space between equally across the joint.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/1\/18\/SplineDovetail_06.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/1\/18\/SplineDovetail_06.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}See the clearly marked-up work piece is now ready for machining.
steps.description: Fit the router with a guide bush and dovetail cutter.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e2\/SplineDovetail_07.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e2\/SplineDovetail_07.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Make a setting bar to help you set up your jig accurately.
steps.description: This should fit snugly in the guide bush groove and have its centre clearly marked.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e3\/SplineDovetail_08.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e3\/SplineDovetail_08.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Insert the setting bar through the jig and line it up on the first of the marked lines on the joint below.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/f\/f2\/SplineDovetail_09.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/f\/f2\/SplineDovetail_09.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Clamp the jig in place so it fits squarely over the mitred workpiece.
steps.description: Check its alignment again with the setting bar.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/8\/86\/SplineDovetail_10.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/8\/86\/SplineDovetail_10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Stand the router on the jig and plunge the cutter until it touches the joint.
steps.description: Set the depth 10mm below this. Pull the router back, plunge to full depth and lock it down.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/56\/SplineDovetail_11.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/56\/SplineDovetail_11.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Start the machine and run it through the joint.
steps.description: Switch off without releasing the plunge lock. Re-set the jig and repeat for all the marked positions across the joint.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/c\/ce\/SplineDovetail_12.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/c\/ce\/SplineDovetail_12.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}After machining, the joint has an evenly spaced series of cleanly-cut sockets.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/0b\/SplineDovetail_13.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/0b\/SplineDovetail_13.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":371,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":613.0666666666667,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Remove the dovetail cutter from the router.
steps.description: Set a sliding bevel to match its cutting angle.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/c\/c3\/SplineDovetail_14.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/c\/c3\/SplineDovetail_14.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":368,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":608,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Transfer this angle setting to your table saw.
steps.description: The crown guard has been removed for clarity here, but must always be fitted when using the saw.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/55\/SplineDovetail_15.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/55\/SplineDovetail_15.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":371,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":613.0666666666667,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Set the rip fence a little wider than the base of the dovetail, and rip down both sides of your timber to make the splines.
steps.description: Prepare a long length; trim it to size later.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/2\/2e\/SplineDovetail_16.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/2\/2e\/SplineDovetail_16.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Adjust the fit.
steps.description: Lay the timber on its side, and with the blade still tilted, take shaving cuts off the bottom until the piece will just fit into the dovetail sockets.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/d2\/SplineDovetail_17.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/d2\/SplineDovetail_17.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Cut the splines into short lengths.
steps.description: Apply a little glue and gently drive one into place in the first socket with a hammer.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/4e\/SplineDovetail_18.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/4e\/SplineDovetail_18.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Repeat the process for the other sockets.
steps.description: Put the joint aside to allow the glue to set.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/00\/SplineDovetail_19.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/00\/SplineDovetail_19.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Trim off the waste with a flexible pull saw.
steps.description: This allows you to trim right up to the edge without damaging the workpiece.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/c\/c0\/SplineDovetail_20.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/c\/c0\/SplineDovetail_20.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}Finally clean up the surface of the joint with fine abrasive paper.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b5\/SplineDovetail_21.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b5\/SplineDovetail_21.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"}The finished joint, with the dark splines contrasting well with the paler wood of the workpiece.

text:
Start by making the jig as shown in the picture and drawing. Use 18mm MDF for strength, and make sure the included angle is exactly 90 degrees to ensure stability. The sizes given are advisory; though keep the top plate as large as possible for maximum router support. The dovetail splines are inserted through an already assembled mitre joint, so the first step is to assemble the joint and glue it up. It’s a good idea to use biscuits to help hold the joint in alignment. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/6/6d/SplineDovetail_04.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/6/6d/SplineDovetail_04.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons

"}Clamp your assembled mitre joint in the bench vice so it faces upwards. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/45/SplineDovetail_05.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/45/SplineDovetail_05.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons

"}Mark out the dovetail spacings across the joint. Start about 10mm in from each edge for the outside pair, and then divide the space between equally across the joint. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/1/18/SplineDovetail_06.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/1/18/SplineDovetail_06.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons

"}See the clearly marked-up work piece is now ready for machining. Fit the router with a guide bush and dovetail cutter. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e2/SplineDovetail_07.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e2/SplineDovetail_07.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons

"}Make a setting bar to help you set up your jig accurately. This should fit snugly in the guide bush groove and have its centre clearly marked. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e3/SplineDovetail_08.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e3/SplineDovetail_08.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons

License: Creative Commons

"}Clamp the jig in place so it fits squarely over the mitred workpiece. Check its alignment again with the setting bar. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/8/86/SplineDovetail_10.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/8/86/SplineDovetail_10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons

"}Stand the router on the jig and plunge the cutter until it touches the joint. Set the depth 10mm below this. Pull the router back, plunge to full depth and lock it down. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/5/56/SplineDovetail_11.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/5/56/SplineDovetail_11.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

"}Start the machine and run it through the joint. Switch off without releasing the plunge lock. Re-set the jig and repeat for all the marked positions across the joint. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/ce/SplineDovetail_12.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/ce/SplineDovetail_12.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

Lay the timber on its side, and with the blade still tilted, take shaving cuts off the bottom until the piece will just fit into the dovetail sockets. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d2/SplineDovetail_17.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d2/SplineDovetail_17.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

Apply a little glue and gently drive one into place in the first socket with a hammer. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/4e/SplineDovetail_18.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/4e/SplineDovetail_18.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

Put the joint aside to allow the glue to set. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/00/SplineDovetail_19.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/00/SplineDovetail_19.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

This allows you to trim right up to the edge without damaging the workpiece. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/c0/SplineDovetail_20.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/c0/SplineDovetail_20.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":337,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":557.3333333333334,"licensing":"

"}The finished joint, with the dark splines contrasting well with the paler wood of the workpiece.
